indicators.title: Vital statistics by sex
indicators.description: Live birth is the complete expulsion or extraction from its mother of a product of conception, which, after such separation, breaths or shows any other evidence of life such as beating of the heart, pulsation of the umbilical cord, or definite movements of voluntary muscles. If a product of such a births dies, it is first registered as live- born and then as died. A dead person is every live-born person in which there is a permanent disappearance of all evidence of life at any time after live birth has taken place, without capability of resuscitation. Stillbirths are not included here.Natural increase is the difference between the number of live births and the number of deaths.

indicators.title: Natural growth rate
indicators.description: The rate of natural growth represents the ratio of the average annual natural increase and the average number of inhabitants in the observed period, calculated per 1000 inhabitants.

indicators.title: Crude birth rate
indicators.description: General natality rate is the ratio between the number of live-born children and the estimated number of inhabitants per 1000 population.

indicators.title: Total fertility rate
indicators.description: The total fertility rate represents the ratio of the number of live births in the observed calendar year and the total population in the fertile period of the same observed year.

indicators.title: Age-specific fertility rate
indicators.description: The total fertility rate represents the ratio of the number of live births in the observed calendar year and the total population in the fertile period of the same observed year.

indicators.title: Sex ratio at birth
indicators.description: The indicator shows the ratio of the number of boys to 100 girls in the total number of live births.

indicators.title: Births by teenage mothers by age group
indicators.description: Childbirth is the end of pregnancy, i.e. gestational period with the birth of one or more newborns from the womans uterus.

indicators.title: Crude death rate
indicators.description: General mortality rate is the ratio between a number of dead and an estimated number of inhabitants per 1000 population.

indicators.title: Infant (up to 12 months of age) mortality by sex
indicators.description: Dead infants are considered children who died under one year of age.

indicators.title: Infant (up to 12 months of age) mortality rate
indicators.description: Infant mortality rate is the ratio between the number of dead infants and the number of live-born children in a given year per per 1000 live-born children.

indicators.title: Deaths by cause of death and sex
indicators.description: A dead person is every live-born person in which there is a permanent disappearance of all evidence of life at any time after live birth has taken place, without capability of resuscitation. Stillbirths are not included here.

indicators.title: Stillbirths by sex
indicators.description: A stillborn child is considered a child born or taken out from mother’s body who exhibits no signs of life (not breathing, not moving, no heartbeat) where pregnancy has lasted more than 22 weeks (approximately 6 lunar months) and weight at childbirth has been 500 gr. or more. Expulsion of a dead fetus carried less than 22 weeks considered a miscarriage (abortion), irrespective of whether natural or artificial. These cases are not registered in population registers, nor shown in the tables on stillborn.

indicators.title: Stillbirth rate
indicators.description: The stillbirth rate represents the ratio between the number of stillbirths and the number of live births in the same year, calculated per 1000 live births.

indicators.title: Average age of mothers at first birth
indicators.description: The average age of the mother at first birth (live birth) is considered to be the average age of the mother at the birth of her first child. For the observed calendar year, the average age at first birth is calculated from specific fertility rates at first birth.

indicators.title: Average age of population by sex
indicators.description: The average age of the population by gender means the average age of its members.

indicators.title: Average age at death by sex
indicators.description: The average age of the dead by gender indicates the average age of the dead persons.

indicators.title: Average age at first marriage by sex
indicators.description: The average age at first marriage is considered to be the average age of a woman (or man) at the time of her first marriage. For the observed year, the average age of a woman (or man) at the time of first marriage is calculated from the rates of first marriage according to the age groups of the bride or groom.

indicators.title: Life expectancy at birth by sex
indicators.description: Life expectancy at birth is the mean number of years a newborn child can expect to live if subjected throughout his or her life to the current mortality conditions, the probabilities of dying at each age.

indicators.title: Marriages
indicators.description: Marriage is a regulated community of life between a woman and a man.

indicators.title: Marriage rate
indicators.description: Marriage rate is the relation between the number of marriage in one year period and the estimated number of inhabitants per 1000 population.

indicators.title: Divorces
indicators.description: A marriage is considered divorced when the court decision on the divorce becomes final.

indicators.title: Divorce rate
indicators.description: Divorce rate is the relation between the number of divorces in one year period and the estimated number of inhabitants per 1000 population.

indicators.title: Projected population by age and sex
indicators.description: The model population projection describes hypothetical futuredevelopment of population size and age-sex structure.

indicators.title: Projected population by age groups and sex
indicators.description: The model population projection describes hypothetical futuredevelopment of population size and age-sex structure.

indicators.title: Projected dependency ratios by sex
indicators.description: The dependency ratio is defined as the ratio of the number of old people (aged 65 and over) compared to the number of people of working age (from 15 to 64).

indicators.title: Projected vital statistics by sex
indicators.description: Live birth is the complete expulsion or extraction from its mother of a product of conception, which, after such separation, breaths or shows any other evidence of life such as beating of the heart, pulsation of the umbilical cord, or definite movements of voluntary muscles. If a product of such a births dies, it is first registered as live- born and then as died. A dead person is every live-born person in which there is a permanent disappearance of all evidence of life at any time after live birth has taken place, without capability of resuscitation. Stillbirths are not included here.Natural increase is the difference between the number of live births and the number of deaths.

indicators.title: Projected crude birth rate
indicators.description: General natality rate is the ratio between the number of live-born children and the estimated number of inhabitants per 1000 population.

indicators.title: Projected crude death rate
indicators.description: General mortality rate is the ratio between a number of dead and an estimated number of inhabitants per 1000 population.

indicators.title: Projected average age of population
indicators.description: The model population projection describes hypothetical futuredevelopment of population size and age-sex structure.

indicators.title: Projected population pyramid
indicators.description: The population pyramid is a graphical representation of the distribution of the population according to age groups and sex. It usually takes the shape of a pyramid when the population grows.

indicators.title: Population by age and sex
indicators.description: In the Censuses of 1971, 1981 and 1991, the concept of „permanent residence“ was applied to determine the total number of the population. The permanent population of a place consists of all persons who permanently live in that place, i.e. have a place of residence, regardless of whether they were in that place at the critical moment of the census or were absent for any other reason, either in the country or abroad. Persons temporarily working abroad with foreign employers or self-employed, as family members staying with them abroad, are listed as permanent residents of the respective settlements in the country where they reside. When comparing data from the 1981 and 1991 Censuses with data from earlier censuses, certain methodological differences in defining the permanent population should be kept in mind. In the censuses of 1961 and 1971, workers who were permanently employed or had a shop in one place and lived in that place, and their families lived in another place, if they did not return daily from their place of work to their family's place of permanent residence , were considered permanent residents of the place where they worked.In the censuses of 1981 and 1991, the place of permanent residence was determined based on the statement of the person being enumerated or a member of the household, so the mentioned category of persons was listed as permanent residents of the settlements where their families lived, not the places where they worked.In the 2013 Census, the concept of “usual residents” was applied for the first time in order to determine the total number of population. Under this concept, a person shall be considered as a resident of the place at which s/he alone (in the case of a one-person household) or with members of her/his household spends most of time, that is, daily rest, irrespective of where the person’s place of residence is registered. Therefore, the total population of a certain place includes persons who lived in that place for a continuous period of at least one year prior to the Census Critical Moment, and persons who at that particular moment lived there less than 12 months but intend to stay at that place for at least one year.

indicators.title: Population by age groups and sex
indicators.description: In the Censuses of 1971, 1981 and 1991, the concept of „permanent residence“ was applied to determine the total number of the population. The permanent population of a place consists of all persons who permanently live in that place, i.e. have a place of residence, regardless of whether they were in that place at the critical moment of the census or were absent for any other reason, either in the country or abroad. Persons temporarily working abroad with foreign employers or self-employed, as family members staying with them abroad, are listed as permanent residents of the respective settlements in the country where they reside. When comparing data from the 1981 and 1991 Censuses with data from earlier censuses, certain methodological differences in defining the permanent population should be kept in mind. In the censuses of 1961 and 1971, workers who were permanently employed or had a shop in one place and lived in that place, and their families lived in another place, if they did not return daily from their place of work to their family's place of permanent residence , were considered permanent residents of the place where they worked.In the censuses of 1981 and 1991, the place of permanent residence was determined based on the statement of the person being enumerated or a member of the household, so the mentioned category of persons was listed as permanent residents of the settlements where their families lived, not the places where they worked.In the 2013 Census, the concept of “usual residents” was applied for the first time in order to determine the total number of population. Under this concept, a person shall be considered as a resident of the place at which s/he alone (in the case of a one-person household) or with members of her/his household spends most of time, that is, daily rest, irrespective of where the person’s place of residence is registered. Therefore, the total population of a certain place includes persons who lived in that place for a continuous period of at least one year prior to the Census Critical Moment, and persons who at that particular moment lived there less than 12 months but intend to stay at that place for at least one year.

indicators.title: Population by municipality, age groups and sex
indicators.description: In the 2013 Census, the concept of „usual residents“ was applied for the first time in order to determine the total number of population. Under this concept, a person shall be considered as a resident of the place at which s/he alone (in the case of a one-person household) or with members of her/his household spends most of time, that is, daily rest, irrespective of where the person’s place of residence is registered. Therefore, the total population of a certain place includes persons who lived in that place for a continuous period of at least one year prior to the Census Critical Moment, and persons who at that particular moment lived there less than 12 months but intend to stay at that place for at least one year.

indicators.title: Population pyramid
indicators.description: The population pyramid is a graphical representation of the distribution of the population according to age groups and sex. It usually takes the shape of a pyramid when the population grows.

indicators.title: Female population aged 15 years and over by number of live-born children
indicators.description: Live birth is the complete expulsion or extraction from its mother of a product of conception, which, after such separation, breaths or shows any other evidence of life such as beating of the heart, pulsation of the umbilical cord, or definite movements of voluntary muscles. If a product of such a births dies, it is first registered as live- born and then as died.

indicators.title: Dependency ratios by sex
indicators.description: The dependency ratio is defined as the ratio of the number of old people (aged 65 and over) compared to the number of people of working age (from 15 to 64).

indicators.title: Households by number of members
indicators.description: A household is considered to be any family or other group of persons (multi-member household), i.e. a group of two or more people who together occupy the entire housing unit or part of it and provide themselves with food and possibly other necessities for life. Every person living alone („single household“) is considered a household, i.e. a person who lives alone in a separate housing unit or who occupies, as a tenant, a separate room (or rooms) in a housing unit, but does not jointly form part of a multi-member household with any tenant of that housing unit.

indicators.title: Households by agricultural activity
indicators.description: A household that performs agricultural activity is a household that answered in the Census of Population, Households and Dwellings that: - in the last 12 months used/cultivated agricultural land for agricultural production on the territory of Bosnia and Herzegovina: arable land and gardens, orchards, vineyards, nurseries and other permanent plantings of meadows and pastures; - or on the day of the Census raised livestock, poultry or bees, including fish and mushroom farming.

indicators.title: Population over 10 years of age by literacy and sex
indicators.description: Literacy data refer to persons aged 10 and over who have no education or incomplete primary education. A person who can read with understanding and write a statement about his everyday life is considered literate, otherwise the person is illiterate.

indicators.title: Population over 15 years of age by educational attainment and sex
indicators.description: Data on the highest school completed refer to persons aged 15 and over. The highest completed school is understood as the type of school by which the person obtained the highest level of education and a diploma or certificate of completion.

indicators.title: Population with disabilities by type of disability, age and sex
indicators.description: Seeing is the ability of a person to use the sense of eyesight and optical abilities in order to notice (see) what is happening around him/her, whether the person uses glasses or lenses. Hearing is the ability of a person to use the sense of hearing in order to hear what he/she is being told or to hear noises surrounding him/her, including also noises pointing to immediate danger, regardless of whether the person uses an hearing aid or not. Walking is the ability of a person to use his/her legs in order to move from point A to point B. The ability to walk has to be without the assistance of another person or orthopaedic device (crutch, walking devices and wheelchairs). If such assistance is necessary, the person has walking limitations. Remembering is the ability of a person to use his/her memory in order to remember the events from his/her environment. This means that a person can remember or think over about something happened in the recent or distant past. Concentration is the ability of a person to use his/her mental abilities for performing tasks such as: reading, calculating, learning something. It is the ability of a person to devote full attention to a certain matter or to focus on one thing without losing concentration. Dressing and maintaining hygiene- this kind of limitation is related to the existence of obstacles when a person cannot take care of himself/herself on his/her won, that is he/she cannot dress, maintain personal hygiene, eat, take an item into his/her hands (clothes, footwear) or open a container, pan, etc. On his/her own, etc. Communication is the ability of a person to exchange information or ideas with other persons. Communication is the ability to use the voice, exchange signs or write information that we wish to exchange. Difficulties to communicate may result from physical limitations, such as impaired sense of hearing or speech problem, or brain inability to interpret sounds that the hearing aid has collected from the environment and, recognizing the words that were uttered.

indicators.title: Infant (up to 12 months of age) mortality by sex
Infant (up to 12 months of age) mortality rate
Deaths by cause of death and sex
Stillbirths by sex
Stillbirth rate
Cervical cancer incidence
indicators.description: The indicator shows the total number of new cases of cervical cancer.

indicators.title: Breast cancer incidence
indicators.description: The indicator shows the total number of new cases of breast cancer.

indicators.title: Cervical cancer incidence per 100,000 female population
indicators.description: The indicator shows the total number of cervical cancers per 100,000 female population.

indicators.title: Breast cancer incidence per 100,000 female population
indicators.description: The indicator shows the total number of new cases of breast cancer per 100,000 female population.

indicators.title: Incidence of syphilis
indicators.description: The indicator shows the total number of new cases of syphilis.

indicators.title: Incidence of gonorrhoea
indicators.description: The indicator shows the total number of new cases of gonorrhea.

indicators.title: Incidence of AIDS
indicators.description: The indicator shows the total number of new AIDS patients

indicators.title: Incidence of HIV
indicators.description: The indicator shows the total number of newly infected persons from HIV

indicators.title: Incidence of HIV per 100,000 population
indicators.description: The indicator shows the total number of newly infected persons from HIV per 100.000 inhabitants

indicators.title: Caesarean sections
indicators.description: The indicator shows the total number of cesarean sections.

indicators.title: Caesarean sections per 1,000 live births
indicators.description: The indicator shows the total number of cesarean sections per 1,000 live births.

indicators.title: Beds in hospitals
indicators.description: The indicator shows the total number of beds in hospitals.

indicators.title: Beds in hospitals per 100,000 population
indicators.description: The indicator shows the total number of beds in hospitals per 100,000 inhabitants.

indicators.title: Physicians employed in health care institutions by sex
indicators.description: The indicator shows the total number of physicians employed in health care institutions.

indicators.title: Obstetricians and gynaecologists employed in health care institutions
indicators.description: The indicator shows the total number of obstetricians and gynecologists employed in health care institutions.

indicators.title: Midwives employed in health care institutions
indicators.description: The indicator shows the total number of midwives employed in health care institutions.

indicators.title: Nurses employed in health care institutions
indicators.description: The indicator shows the total number of medical technicians employed in health care institutions.

indicators.title: Contraceptive prevalence rate
indicators.description: The indicator shows the percentage of women aged 15-49 who used contraceptives.

indicators.title: Unmet need for family planning
indicators.description: The indicator shows the percentage of women aged 15-49 whose need for family planning is not met.

indicators.title: Satisfied demand for family planning
indicators.description: The indicator shows the percentage of women aged 15-49 whose need for family planning is met.

indicators.title: Skilled attendant at delivery
indicators.description: The indicator shows the total number of skilled attendant present in relation to the total number of births.

indicators.title: Population with disabilities by type of disability, age and sex
Social protection beneficiaries by type of beneficiary and sex
indicators.description: Social welfare beneficiary is every person who has used certain forms and measures of social welfare and social work services, once or several times during the reference year. Beneficiaries are classified into two basic age groups – minor and adult beneficiaries. Minor beneficiaries disadvantaged by family situation without both parents, of unknown parents, abandoned by parents, children of parents prevented from performing parental duty, children of parents deprived of parental rights, coming from economically disadvantaged families, coming from families with disturbed family relationships and other minors with disturbed family relationship, then physically and mentally handicapped minors, minors with behavioural and personality disorders and Minor beneficiaries in need of different social and protective services. Adult beneficiares, respectively beneficiaries of subventions are physically and mentally disabled with visual disorders, with hearing disorders, physically disabled, mentally disabled, other disabled persons, persons with combined disorders, persons with socially unacceptable behaviour, mentally ill persons, persons not having a sufficient income to support themselves, financially unprovided.

indicators.title: Social protection beneficiaries by type of institution and sex
indicators.description: Social welfare beneficiary is every person who has used certain forms and measures of social welfare and social work services, once or several times during the reference year. Beneficiaries are classified into two basic age groups – minor and adult beneficiaries. Social welfare institutions are institutions for children and adolescents without parental care, social welfare institutions for mentally and physically handicapped children, adolescents and adults, social welfare institutions for adult disabled persons and social welfare institutions for adult persons.

indicators.title: Preschool institutions by ownership
indicators.description: Pre-school upbringing and education is an activity that includes upbringing and education, care and protection of children from six months of age to entering primary school. It is performed in public and private pre-school institutions.Work with children in preschool institutions is organised in educational groups by age of children. Educational groups can be nursery groups for children from six months until three years of age, kindergarten groups for children from three years of age until the beginning of their school education, and mixed groups for children of various age.

indicators.title: Children in preschool institutions by sex
indicators.description: Pre-school upbringing and education is an activity that includes upbringing and education, care and protection of children from six months of age to entering primary school. It is performed in public and private pre-school institutions.Work with children in preschool institutions is organised in educational groups by age of children. Educational groups can be nursery groups for children from six months until three years of age, kindergarten groups for children from three years of age until the beginning of their school education, and mixed groups for children of various age.

indicators.title: Children in nurseries by sex
indicators.description: Pre-school upbringing and education is an activity that includes upbringing and education, care and protection of children from six months of age to entering primary school. It is performed in public and private pre-school institutions.Work with children in preschool institutions is organised in educational groups by age of children. Educational groups can be nursery groups for children from six months until three years of age, kindergarten groups for children from three years of age until the beginning of their school education, and mixed groups for children of various age.

indicators.title: Childcare workers in preschool institutions by sex
indicators.description: Pre-school upbringing and education is an activity that includes upbringing and education, care and protection of children from six months of age to entering primary school. It is performed in public and private pre-school institutions.Work with children in preschool institutions is organised in educational groups by age of children. Educational groups can be nursery groups for children from six months until three years of age, kindergarten groups for children from three years of age until the beginning of their school education, and mixed groups for children of various age.

indicators.title: Children at the beginning of school year by sex (primary school)
indicators.description: School, in education statistics, is a group of pupils organized into one school unit with one or more teachers who perform certain kind of teaching by certain educational plan and programme, irrespective of a school being central or independent school, a regional unit or a unit within another type of school. Schools are also considered territorially separated units/regional units within basic schools as well as classes for children with special needs, within regular basic schools.

indicators.title: Children who completed primary school by sex
indicators.description: School, in education statistics, is a group of pupils organized into one school unit with one or more teachers who perform certain kind of teaching by certain educational plan and programme, irrespective of a school being central or independent school, a regional unit or a unit within another type of school. Schools are also considered territorially separated units/regional units within basic schools as well as classes for children with special needs, within regular basic schools.

indicators.title: Teachers in primary schools by sex
indicators.description: School, in education statistics, is a group of pupils organized into one school unit with one or more teachers who perform certain kind of teaching by certain educational plan and programme, irrespective of a school being central or independent school, a regional unit or a unit within another type of school. Schools are also considered territorially separated units/regional units within basic schools as well as classes for children with special needs, within regular basic schools.

indicators.title: Children at the beginning of school year by sex (high school)
indicators.description: Secondary school is an institution for performing an activity in the field of secondary education and upbringing. A school performs educational activity by realizing the educational plan and programme. That is an institution where general and vocational knowledge and skills, required for continuing education, are being acquired. School can be established as grammar schools, secondary technical or vocational schools, religious schools, art schools and school for children with disabilities.

indicators.title: Children at the beginning of school year by type of high school
indicators.description: Secondary school is an institution for performing an activity in the field of secondary education and upbringing. A school performs educational activity by realizing the educational plan and programme. That is an institution where general and vocational knowledge and skills, required for continuing education, are being acquired. School can be established as grammar schools, secondary technical or vocational schools, religious schools, art schools and school for children with disabilities.

indicators.title: Children who completed high school by sex
indicators.description: Secondary school is an institution for performing an activity in the field of secondary education and upbringing. A school performs educational activity by realizing the educational plan and programme. That is an institution where general and vocational knowledge and skills, required for continuing education, are being acquired. School can be established as grammar schools, secondary technical or vocational schools, religious schools, art schools and school for children with disabilities.

indicators.title: Children who completed high school by type of school
indicators.description: Secondary school is an institution for performing an activity in the field of secondary education and upbringing. A school performs educational activity by realizing the educational plan and programme. That is an institution where general and vocational knowledge and skills, required for continuing education, are being acquired. School can be established as grammar schools, secondary technical or vocational schools, religious schools, art schools and school for children with disabilities.

indicators.title: Teachers in high schools by sex
indicators.description: Secondary school is an institution for performing an activity in the field of secondary education and upbringing. A school performs educational activity by realizing the educational plan and programme. That is an institution where general and vocational knowledge and skills, required for continuing education, are being acquired. School can be established as grammar schools, secondary technical or vocational schools, religious schools, art schools and school for children with disabilities.

indicators.title: Enrolled in undergraduate studies by sex
indicators.description: Enrolled student is every person enrolled at higher education institution. Higher education institutions are higher education schools and universities.The name higher education school refers to a higher education institution that realises at least one study programme from one field of study.The name university refers to a higher education institution that realises at least five different study programmes from at least three fields of study and academic levels of all three cycles. University has organizational units such as faculties, academies or scientific institutes.

indicators.title: Graduated students by sex
indicators.description: A graduate is a person who obtains a diploma on completed high or higher school, faculty or art academy.

indicators.title: Graduated students by type of education
indicators.description: A graduate is a person who obtains a diploma on completed high or higher school, faculty or art academy.

indicators.title: Enrolled in integrated studies by sex
indicators.description: Enrolled student is every person enrolled at higher education institution. Integrated studies are organised as a single study programme that includes the first and second cycles of studies and is valued with at least 300, that is, 360 ECTS credits.

indicators.title: Students graduated in integrated studies by sex
indicators.description: Upon completition of the integrated studies, person acquires an academic title in a specific field, depending on the type of the completed study programme. Integrated studies are organised as a single study programme that includes the first and second cycles of studies and is valued with at least 300, that is, 360 ECTS credits.

indicators.title: Students graduated in integrated studies by type of education
indicators.description: Upon completition of the integrated studies, person acquires an academic title in a specific field, depending on the type of the completed study programme. Integrated studies are organised as a single study programme that includes the first and second cycles of studies and is valued with at least 300, that is, 360 ECTS credits.

indicators.title: Enrolled in master and specialist studies by sex
indicators.description: Enrolled student is every person enrolled at higher education institution. Second cycle studies are organized upon completion of the first cycle of studies, these last one or two years, and they are valued with 60 or 120 ECTS credits, thus reaching 300 ECTS credits together with the first cycle. The second cycle leads to the academic title of Master or equivalent.

indicators.title: Enrolled in master and specialist studies by type of education
indicators.description: Enrolled student is every person enrolled at higher education institution. Second cycle studies are organized upon completion of the first cycle of studies, these last one or two years, and they are valued with 60 or 120 ECTS credits, thus reaching 300 ECTS credits together with the first cycle. The second cycle leads to the academic title of Master or equivalent.

indicators.title: Students graduated in master and special studies by sex
indicators.description: Master of science is a person who has completed postgraduate studies and defended the master’s thesis. Master is a person who has completed an study of the second cycle, lasting a year or two, valued at 60 ECTS credits or 120 ECTS credits, the total of points of the first and of the second cycle of studies equals 300 ECTS credits. Specialist is a person who has completed specialist studies and defended the specialist’s thesis.

indicators.title: Students graduated in master and special studies by type of education
indicators.description: Master of science is a person who has completed postgraduate studies and defended the master’s thesis. Master is a person who has completed an study of the second cycle, lasting a year or two, valued at 60 ECTS credits or 120 ECTS credits, the total of points of the first and of the second cycle of studies equals 300 ECTS credits. Specialist is a person who has completed specialist studies and defended the specialist’s thesis.

indicators.title: Enrolled in doctoral studies by sex
indicators.description: Enrolled student is every person enrolled at higher education institution. Third cycle studies are organized upon completion of the second cycle of academic studies, or upon completion of integrated studies, these last three years, and they are valued with 180 ECTS credits. The third cycle leads to the academic title of doctor or equivalent.

indicators.title: Enrolled in doctoral studies by type of education
indicators.description: Enrolled student is every person enrolled at higher education institution. Third cycle studies are organized upon completion of the second cycle of academic studies, or upon completion of integrated studies, these last three years, and they are valued with 180 ECTS credits. The third cycle leads to the academic title of doctor or equivalent.

indicators.title: Students graduated in doctoral studies by sex
indicators.description: Doctor of science is a person who has defended doctoral dissertation.

indicators.title: Students graduated in doctoral studies by type of education
indicators.description: Doctor of science is a person who has defended doctoral dissertation.

indicators.title: Population 25-64 years of age enrolled in non-formal, adult education by age groups and sex
indicators.description: Non-formal education is an organized process of learning and education aimed at training adults for work, for various social activities, for personal development and supplementing knowledge, skills and abilities according to special programs carried out by education organizers (schools, training centers, business entities, agencies and similar) and which takes place independently of the official (formal) education system and does not lead to the acquisition of public documents (diplomas and qualifications).

indicators.title: NEET_Population not in employment, education or training by age groups and sex
indicators.description: The indicator presents the share of young people who are not in employment, education or training (NEET), as a percentage of the total number of people in the corresponding age group.

indicators.title: Population over 10 years of age by literacy and sex
Population over 15 years of age by educational attainment and sex
Gross Domestic Product (GDP) in millions
indicators.description: Gross domestic product is a measure of the total value added generated by all resident producer units plus net taxes on products (not included in value added) during the reference period.

indicators.title: Gross Domestic Product (GDP) - Per capita
indicators.description: metadata_fileds.BDP

indicators.title: Real Gross Domestic Product (GDP) growth
indicators.description: The annual real growth rate of gross domestic product represents the percentage change in real GDP between two consecutive years.

indicators.title: Activity rate by age group and sex
indicators.description: The activity rate is the share of the active population (labour force) in the total working age population.

indicators.title: Employment rate by age group and sex
indicators.description: The employment rate is the share of employed persons in the total working age population.

indicators.title: Unemployment rate by age group and sex
indicators.description: Unemployment rate is the share of unemployed persons in the total active population.

indicators.title: Status in employment by gender
indicators.description: Self-employed persons are persons who work independently in their own company, institution, private shop or on an agricultural farm, as well as persons who perform independent professional activity or some other job for their own account. Employees are persons who work for an employer in any form of ownership, regardless of whether they have a formal employment contract or work on the basis of an oral agreement. Contributing family workers (unpaid) are persons who assist another household member in running a family business or farm without being paid for the work.

indicators.title: NEET_Population not in employment, education or training by age groups and sex
Activity rate by age group and sex (quarterly)
indicators.description: The activity rate is the share of the active population (labour force) in the total working age population.

indicators.title: Employment rate by age group and sex (quarterly)
indicators.description: The employment rate is the share of employed persons in the total working age population.

indicators.title: Unemployment rate by age group and sex (quarterly)
indicators.description: Unemployment rate is the share of unemployed persons in the total active population.

indicators.title: Households living in relative poverty
indicators.description: The line of poverty: threshold in contrast with the consumption expenditure by which the households are classified in category of poor households and the ones that are not poor. Relative line of poverty is set at 60% of median of equalized monthly consumption expenditure. The equivalent consumption expenditure of the household: monthly expenditure divided by equivalent size of the household according to so called „modified equivalence scale – OECD“ (the scale of equivalence gives a weight 1,0 to the head of the household, 0,5 to other members aged 14 and over and 0,3 t every child under the age of 14).

indicators.title: Population living in relative poverty by sex
indicators.description: The line of poverty: threshold in contrast with the consumption expenditure by which the households are classified in category of poor households and the ones that are not poor. Relative line of poverty is set at 60% of median of equalized monthly consumption expenditure. The equivalent consumption expenditure of the household: monthly expenditure divided by equivalent size of the household according to so called „modified equivalence scale – OECD“ (the scale of equivalence gives a weight 1,0 to the head of the household, 0,5 to other members aged 14 and over and 0,3 t every child under the age of 14).

indicators.title: Violence against women after the age of 15 (all types)
indicators.description: The indicator shows the total number of women who have experienced psychological, physical or sexual violence since the age of fifteen by a partner or non-partner.
